intro: Mariscus phillipsiae, commonly known as the Phillips' mariscus, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of South America. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided leaves and umbellate inflorescences. The plant typically grows in rocky or gravelly soils at high altitudes, showcasing its adaptability to harsh environments. Its small white or yellow flowers bloom in late summer, attracting various pollinators. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a rare and ecologically significant species.
